item.title: US election: Criminal probe into Trump's 'find the votes' call
item.description: The then-president was recorded asking Georgia officials to find enough votes to reverse his defeat.

item.title: Covid: WHO backs Oxford vaccine 'even if variants present'
item.description: Its use in people over 65 as well as in countries where variants are circulating is recommended.

item.title: Fake Covid videos 'will cost lives'
item.description: Sima Kotecha follows the origins of a "dangerous" viral video about a false Covid-19 treatment.

item.title: Loujain al-Hathloul: Saudi women's rights activist released from prison
item.description: Loujain al-Hathloul was instrumental in the movement to allow women to drive in the kingdom.

item.title: Three Cubans survive on coconuts for 33 days on uninhabited island
item.description: The stranded Cubans, who survived by eating coconuts, were spotted by a US Coast Guard patrol.

item.title: Covid: EU's von der Leyen admits vaccine rollout failures
item.description: Ursula von der Leyen tells the Brussels Parliament "we're still not where we want to be".

item.title: Myanmar coup: Woman shot at protest fights for life
item.description: The woman was reportedly shot in the head by police at a rally in the capital Nay Pyi Taw on Tuesday.

item.title: Robert Irwin: Steve Irwin's son wins award for bushfire image
item.description: The dramatic drone image shows the devastation left by a fire in a conservation area in Australia.

item.title: Florida town allows Donald Trump to stay at his Mar-a-Lago resort
item.description: Some of the former president's neighbours sought to prevent him from living at his private club.

item.title: Cat Zoom: Lawyer Rod Ponton surprised to become internet star
item.description: A Texas lawyer reflects on becoming an internet sensation after a mishap with a cat filter.

item.title: Bitcoin consumes 'more electricity than Argentina'
item.description: The rising value of Bitcoin leads to ever-higher energy consumption, researchers say.

item.title: TikTok's Oracle-Walmart deal could be off
item.description: The Biden administration may be taking a softer line on Chinese tech giants say industry watchers.

item.title: 'Revealing' the unseen virus on film
item.description: Nicola Muirhead's manipulated photos capture the isolation of living with the pandemic.

item.title: Myanmar coup: Pools and princesses as protesters go all out
item.description: Protesters are turning up dressed as princesses, super heroes, witches, and everything in between.

item.title: Trump impeachment: What the Proud Boys did before president's speech
item.description: A detailed examination of video reveals how far right extremists and militia stormed the US Capitol.

item.title: Christina Milian replaces Naya Rivera on Step Up
item.description: The singer and actress is set to replace the late Naya Rivera on the TV series Step Up.

item.title: Covid-19: Downton Abbey's Hugh Bonneville is vaccine marshal
item.description: Hugh Bonneville has been surprising people queuing for the vaccine at a hub near his home.

item.title: Australian Open: How the event is trying to stay Covid-safe
item.description: Tens of thousands of tennis fans are being allowed in each day to watch, after a three week delay.

item.title: Myanmar coup: 'My ex is bad but military is worse'
item.description: Younger protesters have brought their humour to street rallies rejecting the Myanmar military coup.

item.title: Night exercise: Top tips to exercise safely
item.description: One consequence of lockdown has been that neighbourhoods come to life after dark.

item.title: Abducted, trafficked or killed: The life of a sex worker in Sierra Leone
item.description: Africa Eye investigates the disappearance of a sex worker and uncovers abuse, trafficking and murder

item.title: Super Bowl: The history-making women and other highlights
item.description: Here we take a look at standout moments from a Super Bowl restricted by the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Clubhouse: The controversial chats that angered China's censors
item.description: It's hard for Chinese citizens to discuss sensitive topics online, but the Clubhouse app let them - briefly.

item.title: Venezuelans say new legal status 'changes everything'
item.description: Colombia's decision to give a million Venezuelan migrants protected status sparks hope in MedellÃ­n.

item.title: Letter from Africa: How a text book exposed a rift in Sudan's new government
item.description: The row over its inclusion in a school text book exposes a rift between Islamists and secularists.

item.title: A behind-the-scenes peek into President Trump's diplomacy
item.description: A new BBC series explores former President Donald Trump's foreign policy through firsthand accounts.

item.title: Amazon fight with workers: 'You're a cog in the system'
item.description: Activists are trying to unionise Amazon workers in Bessemer, Alabama, which would be a first for the US - if they succeed.

item.title: Covid: How Serbia soared ahead in vaccination campaign
item.description: Leaders in this European country do not care where the vaccines come from as long as they are safe.

item.title: Draghi: Call of duty for Italy's 'Super Mario'
item.description: With Italy's Mario Draghi set to become prime minister, Mark Lowen profiles the man who "saved the euro".

item.title: West Side Story's Rita Moreno: 'J-Lo can't be sole representative' of Latinos
item.description: Oscar-winning Rita Moreno calls for more and better roles for Latin Americans working in film.

item.title: Covid: Why Australia's 'world-class' quarantine system has seen breaches
item.description: Australian cities have entered snap lockdowns over single breaches - what can be done to prevent them?

item.title: Nourin Mohamed Siddig: The African art of reciting the Koran
item.description: Social media has revived African styles of Koranic recitation led by Sudan's Nourin Mohamed Siddig.

item.title: Record-breaking Man City beat Swansea to reach FA Cup last eight
item.description: Manchester City rewrite English football's record books as a comfortable 3-1 victory at Swansea City sends them into the FA Cup quarter-finals.

item.title: The summer for a bargain? Some of Europe's best players are available for free
item.description: With Europe's best players returning to action next week in the Champions League, BBC Sport takes a look at some of the stellar names out of contract this summer.

item.title: Kyrgios thrills Melbourne crowds as Djokovic survives
item.description: Novak Djokovic survives a scare and Nick Kyrgios saves match points as day three at the Australian Open caught the attention of the crowds.

item.title: Can 'intense' Langer adapt to criticism and build a legacy?
item.description: After Australia's series defeat by India, now is the time to see if coach Justin Langer can adapt and turn his reign into a legacy, says Geoff Lemon.

item.title: Dutee Chand: 'I train six times a day, I have to win'
item.description: BBC Indian Sportswoman of the Year nominee Dutee Chand shares her intense training regime.

item.title: Trump lawyer's 'rambling' Senate speech slated
item.description: Bruce Castor has been ridiculed for his rambling 48-minute statement at the impeachment trial.

item.title: Trump impeachment process: Who are the key players?
item.description: These are the lawmakers with a big influence on the impeachment process against the former president.

item.title: Trump impeachment: Fact-checking the Senate trial
item.description: Donald Trump's lawyers are disputing his impeachment on several fronts - are they right?

item.title: Trump impeachment video: What was in it?
item.description: Democrats opened their case with a chilling and violent 13-minute montage of Capitol riots footage.

item.title: Trump impeachment: The terror of being trapped in the US Capitol
item.description: Three members of Congress describe in vivid detail what they saw as rioters stormed the building.

item.title: Capitol riots: Five takeaways from the arrests
item.description: Those who have been charged so far come from a variety of backgrounds and at least 41 states.

item.title: 'Their goal is to destroy everyone': Uighur camp detainees allege systematic rape
item.description: In new testimony, former detainees of China's detention camps describe systematic rape and torture.
